faqs.answer: Yes, residents can book international tickets in India for travel between two foreign countries. However, this will count towards their overall LRS limit of USD 250,000.

faqs.question: Is meeting medical expenses of an NRI close relative in India by Resident Individuals permitted?
faqs.answer: Yes, such payments are allowed under 'services related thereto' as per FEMA Notification No. FEMA 14(R)/2016-RB.

faqs.question: Can a person resident in India hold assets outside India?
faqs.answer: Yes, if acquired while being a non-resident or inherited from a non-resident. Residents can also acquire property and assets overseas under the LRS.

faqs.question: What is the definition of MSME?
faqs.answer: As per Government of India Gazette Notification S.O. 2119 (E) dated June 26, 2020: (i) Micro enterprise: Investment in plant and machinery or equipment ≤ ₹1 crore, turnover ≤ ₹5 crore. (ii) Small enterprise: Investment ≤ ₹10 crore, turnover ≤ ₹50 crore. (iii) Medium enterprise: Investment ≤ ₹50 crore, turnover ≤ ₹250 crore. Registration on Udyam Registration Portal is required.

faqs.question: What is the status of lending by banks to MSMEs?
faqs.answer: Bank loans to MSMEs engaged in manufacturing or services are classified under Priority Sector Lending (PSL), per Government of India guidelines and RBI circulars.

faqs.question: Can retail and wholesale trade be classified under MSME?
faqs.answer: Yes. The Ministry of MSME, via Office Memorandum dated July 2, 2021, allowed Udyam registration for retail and wholesale trade.

faqs.question: What is meant by Priority Sector Lending?
faqs.answer: Priority sector lending focuses on sectors impacting large populations, weaker sections, and employment-intensive industries such as agriculture and MSMEs.

faqs.question: Are there any targets prescribed for lending by banks to MSMEs?
faqs.answer: Yes. A sub-target of 7.5% of Adjusted Net Bank Credit (ANBC) or Credit Equivalent of Off-Balance Sheet Exposure (CEOBE) is prescribed for lending to Micro enterprises.

faqs.question: How do banks assess the working capital requirements of MSME borrowers?
faqs.answer: Banks appraise credit needs based on the business cycle and short-term requirements. As per the Nayak Committee Report, working capital limits are computed as a minimum of 20% of estimated turnover (up to ₹5 crore credit limit).

faqs.question: Is there a provision for granting composite loans by banks?
faqs.answer: Yes. Banks can sanction composite loans up to ₹1 crore covering both working capital and term loan requirements under a Single Window.

faqs.question: What is Cluster Financing?
faqs.answer: Cluster financing is a full-service approach catering to the diverse needs of MSMEs in specific geographic clusters. It helps banks in risk assessment, cost reduction, and targeted financial services.

faqs.question: What are the RBI guidelines on interest rates for loans disbursed by banks?
faqs.answer: Interest rates are deregulated and governed by banks' lending policies. From October 1, 2019, MSME loans are linked to an external benchmark for better monetary policy transmission.

faqs.question: Can MSME borrowers get collateral-free loans from banks?
faqs.answer: Yes. Banks are mandated not to accept collateral for loans up to ₹10 lakh for MSME units.

faqs.question: What is the Credit Guarantee Fund Trust Scheme for MSEs?
faqs.answer: The scheme, set up by the Ministry of MSME and SIDBI, provides credit guarantees up to ₹200 lakh for collateral-free loans to MSMEs.

faqs.question: Is credit rating mandatory for MSME borrowers?
faqs.answer: No. Credit rating by external agencies is not mandatory if total exposure to a counterparty does not exceed ₹7.5 crore.

faqs.question: What are the guidelines for delayed payment of dues to MSME borrowers?
faqs.answer: (i) Payment must be made within 45 days of the agreed date. (ii) Failure to pay results in compound interest at three times the RBI Bank Rate. (iii) Disputes are referred to the Micro and Small Enterprises Facilitation Council.

faqs.question: How can a bank or creditor identify incipient stress in an MSME account?
faqs.answer: Banks classify stressed accounts into SMA-0 (potential stress), SMA-1 (overdue 31-60 days), and SMA-2 (overdue 61-90 days) before they turn into NPAs.

faqs.question: What is the Framework for Revival and Rehabilitation of MSMEs?
faqs.answer: (i) MSMEs can voluntarily initiate proceedings. (ii) Banks categorize stressed accounts as SMA-0, SMA-1, and SMA-2. (iii) A Committee decides on Corrective Action Plans (CAP), including rectification, restructuring, or recovery.

faqs.question: Which MSME accounts are covered under the Framework for Revival and Rehabilitation?
faqs.answer: The framework applies to MSMEs with loan limits up to ₹25 crore, including consortium and multiple banking arrangements.

faqs.question: What are the RBI guidelines on the One Time Settlement Scheme (OTS) for MSMEs?
faqs.answer: Banks are advised to implement a non-discretionary OTS scheme, approved by their Boards, to settle NPAs of MSMEs.

faqs.question: Do banks provide guidance to MSME entrepreneurs?
faqs.answer: Yes. Banks offer training via Rural Self Employment Training Institutes (RSETIs) and Financial Literacy Centres (FLCs) to educate MSMEs on financial planning and credit management.

faqs.question: Is there a guideline for facilitating timely and adequate credit flow during the MSME life cycle?
faqs.answer: Yes. Banks must extend standby credit, additional working capital, and mid-term reviews based on actual sales.

faqs.question: What is Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS)?
faqs.answer: TReDS is an electronic platform that enables MSMEs to discount trade receivables and access finance quickly.

faqs.question: What is the Certified Credit Counsellors (CCC) Scheme?
faqs.answer: Certified Credit Counsellors (CCCs) are professionals registered with SIDBI who assist MSMEs in preparing project reports to improve bank credit decisions.

faqs.question: When did the Payment and Settlement Systems Act, 2007 (PSS Act, 2007) come into effect?
faqs.answer: The PSS Act, 2007 received the assent of the President on December 20, 2007, and came into force on August 12, 2008.

faqs.question: What is the objective of the PSS Act, 2007?
faqs.answer: The Act regulates and supervises payment systems in India, designating the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) as the authority for related matters. It also provides the legal basis for 'netting' and 'settlement finality'.

faqs.question: What are the regulations made under the PSS Act, 2007 and when did they come into force?
faqs.answer: Two regulations were introduced: (i) The Board for Regulation and Supervision of Payment and Settlement Systems Regulations, 2008, and (ii) The Payment and Settlement Systems Regulations, 2008. Both came into force on August 12, 2008.

faqs.question: What are the objectives of these two regulations?
faqs.answer: The first regulation deals with the composition, powers, and functions of the Board for Regulation and Supervision of Payment and Settlement Systems (BPSS). The second covers authorization, payment instructions, reporting requirements, and compliance for system providers.

faqs.question: Does the PSS Act, 2007 define key terms like 'payment obligation', 'payment instruction', and 'payment system'?
faqs.answer: Yes, these terms are defined under Section 2(1) of the Act.

faqs.question: What is a 'Payment Obligation'?
faqs.answer: It refers to what one participant owes another in a payment system, resulting from clearing, settlement, or payment instructions.

faqs.question: What is a 'Payment Instruction'?
faqs.answer: It is any instrument, authorization, or order (manual or electronic) that facilitates a payment between individuals or participants in a payment system.

faqs.question: What is a 'Settlement'?
faqs.answer: It is the settlement of payment instructions, including those related to securities, foreign exchange, derivatives, or other transactions, which may occur on a net or gross basis.

faqs.question: What is a 'Payment System' under the PSS Act, 2007?
faqs.answer: A system that enables payment between a payer and a beneficiary, involving clearing, payment, or settlement services, excluding stock exchanges and their clearing corporations.

faqs.question: Are entities operating a payment system required to get authorization?
faqs.answer: Yes. As per Section 4 of the Act, no person except the RBI can operate a payment system without authorization.

faqs.question: Is there an application fee for authorization?
faqs.answer: Yes, a fee of ₹10,000 (excluding GST) is required, payable via cash, cheque, demand draft, or electronic transfer.

faqs.question: Are foreign entities allowed to operate a payment system in India?
faqs.answer: Yes, the PSS Act does not differentiate between foreign and domestic entities. However, they must obtain authorization from RBI.

faqs.question: What are Financial Market Infrastructures (FMIs)?
faqs.answer: FMIs are multilateral systems for clearing, settling, or recording financial transactions, including payment systems, central securities depositories (CSDs), and trade repositories (TRs).

faqs.question: What factors does the RBI consider while granting authorization?
faqs.answer: The RBI assesses the need for the system, technical standards, security, risk management, financial status, experience of management, consumer protection, and impact on monetary policies.

faqs.question: Can the RBI refuse or revoke authorization?
faqs.answer: Yes. The RBI can refuse authorization with written notice and a hearing opportunity. It can also revoke authorization if the entity violates terms of authorization.

faqs.question: Is there an appellate authority for applicants whose authorization is refused?
faqs.answer: Yes, they can appeal to the Central Government within 30 days of receiving the refusal notice.

faqs.question: Can the RBI impose security deposits or fees?
faqs.answer: Yes, the RBI is empowered to collect authorization fees and request security deposits from system providers.

faqs.question: Can the RBI lay down operational standards for payment systems?
faqs.answer: Yes, the RBI can prescribe payment instruction formats, operational timings, netting procedures, and membership criteria.

faqs.question: Does the RBI have the authority to inspect system providers?
faqs.answer: Yes, RBI officials can inspect premises, equipment, and documents related to payment systems.

faqs.question: Can RBI issue directions to payment system providers?
faqs.answer: Yes, RBI can direct providers to ensure compliance and smooth operation of payment systems.

faqs.question: Does the PSS Act deal with netting and settlement finality?
faqs.answer: Yes, it legally recognizes settlement finality and ensures that settlements remain irrevocable even if a system participant becomes insolvent.

faqs.question: What are the duties of a system provider under the PSS Act, 2007?
faqs.answer: A system provider must comply with the Act, its regulations, and RBI directions while ensuring operational transparency, confidentiality, and fair treatment of system participants.

faqs.question: How are disputes in payment systems settled?
faqs.answer: Disputes between system participants are resolved through an internal panel. If unresolved, they can be referred to the RBI or, in certain cases, the Central Government.

faqs.question: What are the consequences of dishonoring an electronic fund transfer under the PSS Act, 2007?
faqs.answer: Dishonoring an electronic transfer due to insufficient funds is an offense punishable with imprisonment or fine, similar to cheque dishonor under the Negotiable Instruments Act.

faqs.question: What penalties can be imposed under the PSS Act, 2007?
faqs.answer: Operating a payment system without authorization, non-compliance with RBI directions, or providing false information can result in fines or criminal prosecution.

faqs.question: For what purposes can I seek a first-time home loan?
faqs.answer: You can seek a first-time home loan for purchasing a house or flat, renovation, extension, and repairs to an existing house. Some banks have separate policies for those buying a second house.

faqs.question: How does a bank determine home loan eligibility?
faqs.answer: A bank assesses eligibility based on repayment capacity, which considers disposable income, spouse's income, assets, liabilities, and stability of income. Typically, banks assume 55-60% of disposable income is available for loan repayment.

faqs.question: What is an EMI?
faqs.answer: An EMI (Equated Monthly Installment) is a fixed monthly payment comprising both principal and interest. It starts from the month after full loan disbursement.

faqs.question: What documents are required for loan approval?
faqs.answer: Required documents include identity and residence proof, latest salary slip or Form 16, last six months' bank statements, legal documents of the property, and a completed application form with photographs.

faqs.question: What are the different interest rate options offered by banks?
faqs.answer: Banks offer Fixed Rate Loans (interest remains constant) and Floating Rate Loans (varies with market rates). Some banks also provide step-up and step-down repayment options.

faqs.question: What is the monthly reducing balance method?
faqs.answer: In this method, interest is calculated on the outstanding principal at the end of each month. As principal reduces, the interest component also decreases over time.

faqs.question: How does tenure affect the cost of a loan?
faqs.answer: Longer tenure results in lower EMIs but higher total interest paid, whereas shorter tenure increases EMI but reduces the overall cost of the loan.

faqs.question: What is an amortization schedule?
faqs.answer: An amortization schedule details the periodic principal and interest payments along with the remaining loan balance over time.

faqs.question: What is pre-EMI interest?
faqs.answer: Pre-EMI interest is payable on partial disbursement of the loan before full disbursement. It is calculated on the amount disbursed and paid monthly until EMI starts.

faqs.question: What security is required for a home loan?
faqs.answer: Typically, banks require a first mortgage of the property. Additional collateral such as life insurance policies, securities, or third-party guarantees may be required.

faqs.question: What precautions should be taken when purchasing an old property?
faqs.answer: Ensure original documents, check for encumbrances, verify the title, and review tax papers to confirm ownership legitimacy.

faqs.question: How should borrowers deal with banks when applying for a loan?
faqs.answer: Borrowers should compare loan offers, check interest rates, fees, and repayment terms, negotiate terms, and get written agreements before finalizing a loan.

faqs.question: Can home loans be repaid ahead of schedule?
faqs.answer: Yes, but some banks charge prepayment penalties of 2-3%. Some banks waive prepayment charges if payments are made from personal savings rather than another loan.

faqs.question: What are switch-over or balance transfer charges?
faqs.answer: Banks charge a switch-over fee when transferring a loan from one bank to another offering lower interest rates. It is typically lower than prepayment charges.

faqs.question: Are tax benefits available on home loans?
faqs.answer: Yes. Interest payments up to ₹1,50,000 per year and principal repayments up to ₹1,00,000 per year qualify for tax benefits under the Income Tax Act, 1961.

faqs.question: What are the minimum standards banks must follow when offering home loans?
faqs.answer: Banks must provide clear information on interest rates, fees, and charges, supply authenticated copies of loan documents, and give valid reasons for loan rejection.

faqs.question: How can borrowers file complaints against banks regarding home loans?
faqs.answer: Borrowers can file complaints with the bank. If unresolved within 30 days, complaints can be submitted to the Banking Ombudsman via www.bankingombudsman.rbi.org.in.

faqs.question: What is a Reverse Mortgage Loan?
faqs.answer: Reverse mortgage loans are available for senior citizens (above 60) who own a house but lack sufficient income. They receive periodic payments while retaining homeownership.

faqs.question: What is an Automated Teller Machine (ATM)?
faqs.answer: An ATM is a computerized machine that allows bank customers to access their accounts for cash withdrawal and other financial & non-financial transactions without visiting a bank branch.

faqs.question: What are White Label ATMs (WLAs)?
faqs.answer: WLAs are ATMs set up, owned, and operated by non-bank entities authorized by the RBI under the Payment & Settlement Systems Act, 2007.

faqs.question: Are there differences in facilities available at bank ATMs and WLAs?
faqs.answer: For customers, using a WLA is similar to using a bank ATM. However, certain services like mobile recharges are not available at WLAs.

faqs.question: Why were WLAs introduced?
faqs.answer: WLAs were introduced to improve ATM availability, especially in semi-urban and rural areas.

faqs.question: What services are available at ATMs/WLAs?
faqs.answer: Services include cash withdrawal, account information, bill payments, mini-statements, PIN change, and cheque book requests.

faqs.question: What types of cards can be used at ATMs/WLAs?
faqs.answer: ATM cards, debit cards, credit cards, and prepaid cards, as permitted by the issuer, can be used at ATMs/WLAs.

faqs.question: What are the prerequisites for using an ATM/WLA?
faqs.answer: Customers need a valid card and PIN. RBI has also permitted cardless withdrawals at ATMs.

faqs.question: What is a PIN?
faqs.answer: A PIN (Personal Identification Number) is a numeric password provided by the bank to secure transactions. Customers should change their PIN regularly and not share it.

faqs.question: Can ATM cards issued by banks in India be used at any ATM/WLA?
faqs.answer: Yes, ATM cards issued by banks in India can be used at any ATM/WLA in the country.

faqs.question: What are On-Us and Off-Us transactions?
faqs.answer: An On-Us transaction occurs at an ATM of the card-issuing bank, whereas an Off-Us transaction occurs at an ATM of another bank or a WLA.

faqs.question: Are customers entitled to free transactions at ATMs?
faqs.answer: Yes, banks must provide a minimum number of free ATM transactions for savings account holders, including at their own ATMs and other bank ATMs.

faqs.question: Can banks offer more free ATM transactions?
faqs.answer: Yes, while RBI mandates a minimum number of free transactions, banks may offer additional free transactions.

faqs.question: Are Basic Savings Bank Deposit Accounts (BSBDA) eligible for free ATM transactions?
faqs.answer: The prescribed free transaction limit does not apply to BSBDA accounts, as the number of withdrawals is subject to account-specific conditions.

faqs.question: Are there any transactions excluded from the free transaction count?
faqs.answer: Non-cash withdrawal transactions at the issuing bank’s ATMs and failed transactions due to technical reasons are not counted as chargeable ATM transactions.

faqs.question: How can a customer determine if an ATM is in a metro or non-metro location?
faqs.answer: ATM locations must display clear signage indicating whether they are in a metro or non-metro area.

faqs.question: Are customers charged for ATM transactions?
faqs.answer: Yes, customers are charged beyond the free transaction limit. Charges are capped at ₹21 per transaction (plus taxes).

faqs.question: What are the charges for using credit cards at ATMs or making withdrawals abroad?
faqs.answer: Charges for cash withdrawals using credit cards and withdrawals at ATMs abroad are determined by individual banks.

faqs.question: What should a customer do if an ATM transaction fails but the account is debited?
faqs.answer: Banks are expected to reverse such transactions automatically, but customers should also lodge a complaint with the issuing bank.

faqs.question: Where can customers find contact details for lodging ATM transaction complaints?
faqs.answer: Banks/WLA operators must display contact details (toll-free numbers/help desk contacts) at ATMs.

faqs.question: What is the time limit for banks to reverse failed ATM transactions?
faqs.answer: Banks must recredit the customer’s account within a maximum of 5 calendar days (T+5, where ‘T’ is the transaction date).

faqs.question: Are customers compensated for delays in reversing failed transactions?
faqs.answer: Yes, banks must compensate customers ₹100 per day for delays beyond 5 days, without requiring a claim from the customer.

faqs.question: What can a customer do if the bank does not process a reversal or compensation?
faqs.answer: If unresolved within 30 days, customers can file a complaint under the RBI Ombudsman Scheme via https://cms.rbi.org.in.

faqs.question: What should be done with an expired ATM card or a closed account?
faqs.answer: Expired or closed-account ATM cards should be cut into four pieces through the magnetic strip/chip before disposal.

faqs.question: How can customers ensure security during ATM/WLA transactions?
faqs.answer: Customers should keep PINs private, avoid sharing cards, register for SMS alerts, be aware of skimming devices, and report suspicious activity.

faqs.question: What should be done if an ATM card is lost or stolen?
faqs.answer: Customers should immediately contact their bank to block the card.

faqs.question: What are Magnetic Stripe cards and EMV Chip & PIN cards?
faqs.answer: Magnetic Stripe cards store data on a stripe, while EMV Chip & PIN cards store data in an embedded chip for enhanced security.

faqs.question: What is the RBI mandate on Magnetic Stripe and EMV Chip & PIN cards?
faqs.answer: All banks were required to replace Magnetic Stripe cards with EMV Chip & PIN cards by December 31, 2018.

faqs.question: Which types of cards are allowed for withdrawing cash at PoS terminals?
faqs.answer: Cardholders can withdraw cash using their debit cards and full KYC prepaid cards issued by banks and non-banks in India. Credit cards cannot be used for this facility. Cash can also be withdrawn through UPI and electronic cards linked with overdraft facilities under PMJDY accounts.

faqs.question: Is there any limit on the amount of cash that can be withdrawn under this facility?
faqs.answer: Yes, a cardholder can withdraw up to ₹2,000 per transaction within an overall monthly limit of ₹10,000.

faqs.question: What are the charges for availing this facility?
faqs.answer: Charges, if any, shall not exceed 1% of the transaction amount.

faqs.question: Is this facility available at all merchant establishments? How will I know if the facility is available at a particular merchant PoS?
faqs.answer: No, this facility is available only at designated merchant establishments selected by acquirer banks after due diligence. Merchants offering this service must clearly display its availability along with applicable charges.

faqs.question: Is withdrawal of cash using PoS terminals deployed by other banks (i.e. banks other than my card issuer) at designated merchant establishments permitted?
faqs.answer: Yes, cash can be withdrawn from PoS terminals at designated merchant establishments, regardless of whether the card issuer and acquiring bank are the same.

faqs.question: Is it mandatory for the cardholder to purchase some goods or services from the merchant establishment to avail this facility?
faqs.answer: No, cash withdrawal at PoS terminals is permitted even without making a purchase.

faqs.question: Will a receipt be provided for the cash withdrawn at a PoS terminal?
faqs.answer: Yes, the merchant is required to provide a printed receipt generated by the PoS terminal. If the withdrawal is made alongside a purchase, the receipt must separately indicate the cash withdrawal amount.

faqs.question: Where can a grievance in respect of this facility be lodged?
faqs.answer: Customers can lodge grievances with their card issuer. If the issue remains unresolved or the response is unsatisfactory, they can approach the RBI Integrated Ombudsman Scheme, 2021 for redressal.

faqs.question: Does the acquirer bank need any permission from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) for providing this facility at its PoS terminals?
faqs.answer: No, acquirer banks (except local area banks) can provide this facility with the approval of their Board. Local area banks require RBI approval.

faqs.question: What is the Indian currency called and what is its symbol?
faqs.answer: The Indian currency is called the Indian Rupee (INR). One Rupee consists of 100 Paise. The symbol of the Indian Rupee is ₹, resembling both the Devanagari letter '₹' (ra) and the Latin capital letter 'R' with a double horizontal line.

faqs.question: What is legal tender?
faqs.answer: Legal Tender refers to coins or banknotes that must be accepted for the payment of debt or obligations. Banknotes issued by the RBI and ₹1 notes issued by the Government of India are legal tender. Coins up to ₹1,000 and fifty paise coins up to ₹10 are legal tender unless voluntarily accepted beyond these limits.

faqs.question: Where are banknotes and coins produced/minted?
faqs.answer: Banknotes are printed at four currency presses in India (Nasik, Dewas, Mysuru, and Salboni). Coins are minted at four government-owned mints (Mumbai, Hyderabad, Kolkata, NOIDA).

faqs.question: What is a currency chest?
faqs.answer: A currency chest is a storehouse maintained by scheduled banks, authorized by the RBI, for storing and distributing banknotes and coins on behalf of the Reserve Bank. As of March 31, 2024, there were 2,794 currency chests in India.

faqs.question: What is a small coin depot?
faqs.answer: A small coin depot is an authorized bank facility that stocks and distributes small denomination coins (less than ₹1) to other bank branches. As of March 31, 2024, there were 2,460 small coin depots.

faqs.question: What is the role of the Reserve Bank of India in currency management?
faqs.answer: The RBI has the sole right to issue banknotes in India, determines the quantity of notes to be printed, ensures circulation of good quality notes, and destroys soiled or mutilated notes. The Government of India designs and mints coins, while the RBI is responsible for their distribution.

faqs.question: Where can one find information regarding notes/coins supplied by RBI or currently in circulation?
faqs.answer: Information on notes and coins supplied by the RBI is available at: https://rbi.org.in/Scripts/AnnualReportMainDisplay.aspx

faqs.question: How does the Reserve Bank distribute currency to the people?
faqs.answer: The RBI manages currency operations through 19 Issue Offices and a network of currency chests and small coin depots maintained by scheduled banks. Fresh banknotes are sent from printing presses to RBI Issue Offices and then to currency chests, while coins are sent from mints to RBI offices and then distributed to small coin depots.

faqs.question: What is the meaning of 'I promise to pay' clause on the banknotes?
faqs.answer: The 'I promise to pay the bearer the sum of Rupees …' clause represents the RBI's obligation to pay the value of the banknote on demand.

faqs.question: Which denomination banknotes are currently in circulation?
faqs.answer: Banknotes of ₹10, ₹20, ₹50, ₹100, ₹200, ₹500, and ₹2000 are in circulation. ₹1 notes are issued by the Government of India. ₹2 and ₹5 notes have been discontinued but remain legal tender.

faqs.question: Can banknotes be issued only in these denominations?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. As per Section 24 of the RBI Act, banknotes can be issued in values up to ₹10,000 or other denominations specified by the Central Government.

faqs.question: What was the highest denomination note ever printed?
faqs.answer: The highest denomination banknote ever printed by the RBI was ₹10,000, first issued in 1938, demonetized in 1946, reintroduced in 1954, and finally demonetized in 1978.

faqs.question: What is currency paper made up of?
faqs.answer: Indian banknotes are printed on 100% cotton-based paper.

faqs.question: How many languages appear in the language panel of Indian banknotes?
faqs.answer: In addition to Hindi and English, 15 languages appear on the language panel of Indian banknotes.

faqs.question: Is it possible to have two or more banknotes with the same serial number?
faqs.answer: Yes, banknotes can have the same serial number but will differ in the Inset Letter, year of printing, or the signature of a different RBI Governor.

faqs.question: What is non-sequential numbering?
faqs.answer: Non-sequential numbering, introduced in 2011, allows banknote packets of 100 notes to have random serial numbers to improve efficiency and cost-effectiveness in printing.

faqs.question: What is a 'star series' banknote?
faqs.answer: Star series banknotes are replacement notes for defectively printed banknotes in a 100-piece packet. They have a * (star) symbol in the number panel.

faqs.question: Who decides on the design and volume of new banknotes?
faqs.answer: The design is approved by the Central Government after recommendations from the RBI. The volume of notes is determined based on demand, replacement needs, and macroeconomic factors.

faqs.question: Are the banknotes issued by RBI backed by any assets?
faqs.answer: Yes, all banknotes issued by the RBI are backed by assets such as gold, Government Securities, and Foreign Currency Assets as per Section 33 of the RBI Act, 1934.

faqs.question: What are the various types of banknotes issued since independence?
faqs.answer:
India has issued multiple series of banknotes:
1. **Ashoka Pillar Series (1949-1987)** - Featured the Ashoka Pillar instead of King George.
2. **Mahatma Gandhi Series (1996 & 2005)** - Featured Gandhi’s portrait and advanced security features.
3. **Mahatma Gandhi (New) Series (2016-Present)** - Introduced smaller-sized notes with new themes.

faqs.question: Which denomination banknotes have been demonetized?
faqs.answer: ₹500, ₹1000, and ₹10000 notes were demonetized in 1946. ₹1000, ₹5000, and ₹10000 notes were demonetized in 1978. ₹500 and ₹1000 notes were withdrawn on November 8, 2016.

faqs.question: What is the status of withdrawal of pre-2005 series banknotes?
faqs.answer: Pre-2005 banknotes were withdrawn due to fewer security features. They can still be exchanged at RBI Issue Offices.

faqs.question: What happens to the old design banknotes when a new design is introduced?
faqs.answer: Both old and new design notes circulate together for a while, after which old design notes are gradually withdrawn.

faqs.question: What is the need for printing different series of banknotes?
faqs.answer: Central banks the world over change the design of their banknotes and introduce new security features primarily to make counterfeiting difficult and to stay ahead of counterfeiters. India also follows the same policy.

faqs.question: What are the Security Features of banknotes in circulation?

answer.Security Thread: Silver-colored, machine-readable thread in ₹10, ₹20, and ₹50 is windowed on the front and fully embedded on the reverse. ₹100 and above have a color-shifting thread (green to blue).
answer.Intaglio Printing: Portrait of Mahatma Gandhi, RBI seal, Governor's signature, and other features printed in intaglio for ₹100 and above.
answer.See Through Register: Part of the numeral is printed on the obverse and the other part on the reverse, appearing as one when held against light.
answer.Water Mark: Mahatma Gandhi's portrait with light and shade effect and an electrotype mark displaying the denomination.
answer.Colour Shifting Ink: Numerals in ₹200, ₹500, and ₹2000 appear green when held flat and change to blue at an angle.
answer.Fluorescence: Number panels and optical fibers fluoresce under UV light.
answer.Latent Image: Vertical band near Gandhi's portrait contains a latent image showing the denomination (₹20 and above).
answer.Micro Letterings: Small inscriptions visible under a magnifying glass.

New Features (2015 Onwards).New Numbering Pattern: Numerals in the number panels increase in size from left to right.
New Features (2015 Onwards).Angular Bleed Lines: Different patterns in ₹100, ₹200, ₹500, and ₹2000 banknotes for identification.

faqs.question: How can one distinguish the MG series-2005 banknotes?
faqs.answer: The MG Series-2005 banknotes have the year of printing on the reverse, a feature not present in the pre-2005 series.

faqs.question: What features on the Mahatma Gandhi (New) Series (MGNS) banknotes help visually challenged people?
faqs.answer: The banknotes have a sharp color contrast, angular bleed lines, and identification marks in different shapes: Rectangle for ₹2000, Circle for ₹500, 'H' for ₹200, Triangle for ₹100. The numerals are also prominently displayed in raised print.

faqs.question: What is Mobile Aided Note Identifier (MANI)?
faqs.answer: MANI is an RBI-launched mobile app for visually impaired persons to identify Indian banknotes using front or reverse side scans. The app does not authenticate a note as genuine or counterfeit.

faqs.question: What are the quality control measures in currency note printing?
faqs.answer: Banknote quality is maintained within strict tolerance parameters for dimensions, design placement, and print features, following global best practices.

faqs.question: What are soiled, mutilated, and imperfect banknotes?

answer.Soiled Note: A note that has become dirty due to wear and tear, including two-piece notes pasted together.
answer.Mutilated Banknote: A note with a missing portion or composed of more than two pieces.
answer.Imperfect Banknote: A note that is obliterated, shrunk, washed, altered, or indecipherable but not mutilated.

faqs.question: Where can soiled/mutilated banknotes be exchanged?
faqs.answer: All commercial banks are authorized to accept and exchange soiled and mutilated banknotes. Small Finance Banks and Payment Banks may exchange them at their discretion.

faqs.question: What is Clean Note Policy?
faqs.answer: RBI's initiative to maintain the quality of banknotes by urging the public not to staple, write on, or misuse banknotes.

faqs.question: What are the legal provisions for counterfeit notes?
faqs.answer: Sections 489A to 489E of the Indian Penal Code criminalize counterfeiting banknotes, possession, and circulation, with punishments ranging from fines to life imprisonment.

faqs.question: Which denominations of coins are currently in circulation?
faqs.answer: Coins of 50 paise, ₹1, ₹2, ₹5, ₹10, and ₹20 are in circulation. Coins can be issued up to ₹1000 under The Coinage Act, 2011.

faqs.question: Where can one complain against the non-acceptance of coins or exchange of notes and coins by banks?
faqs.answer: Complaints can be lodged at the concerned bank branch. If unresolved, complaints can be taken to the Banking Ombudsman Scheme, 2006 or RBI’s Consumer Education and Protection Cell.

faqs.question: Whether a lending transaction would fall under the definition of digital lending only if all the processes in the life cycle of a loan, viz., customer acquisition, credit assessment, loan approval, disbursement, recovery, and associated customer service, are carried out digitally or some of the aforesaid processes can be carried out in physical mode also?
faqs.answer: The phrase ‘largely by use of seamless digital technologies’ has been used in the Digital Lending definition to accord operational flexibility to REs in ‘Digital Lending’. Therefore, even if some physical interface with customer is present, the lending will still fall under the definition of Digital Lending. However, while doing so, the REs should ensure that the intent behind the Guidelines is adhered to.

faqs.question: Whether any service provider to whom RE has outsourced some of its credit intermediation activities would fall within the definition of Lending Service Provider (LSP) even if the lending transaction in question does not fall under the definition of ‘Digital Lending’?
faqs.answer: Para 1 of the Annex I to the Circular dated September 02, 2022 specifies that these Guidelines are applicable to ‘Digital Lending’. Hence, only if a lending transaction qualifies under the definition of ‘Digital Lending’, will the service provider facilitating such lending be designated as LSP.

faqs.question: Whether all LSPs need to appoint Grievance Redressal Officers?
faqs.answer: Only those LSPs which have an interface with the borrowers would need to appoint a nodal Grievance Redressal Officer. However, it may be reiterated that the RE shall remain responsible for ensuring resolution of complaints arising out of actions of all LSPs engaged by them.

faqs.question: Will EMI programmes on Credit Card undertaken in accordance with the Master Direction on Credit Card and Debit Card – Issuance and Conduct, 2022 be covered within the ambit on Digital Lending Guidelines?
faqs.answer: EMI programmes on Credit Card are governed specifically by Para 6(b)(iii) of the ‘Master Direction on Credit Card and Debit Card – Issuance and Conduct, 2022’. Such transactions shall not be covered under the Guidelines on Digital Lending. However, other loan products offered on Credit Cards which are not covered/ envisaged under the aforesaid para of the Master Direction shall be governed by the stipulations laid down under the Guidelines on Digital Lending. Further, the Guidelines will also be applicable to all loans offered on Debit Card, including EMI programmes.

faqs.question: How to disclose APR in case of floating rate loans?
faqs.answer: In case of floating rate loans, APR may be disclosed at the time of origination based on the prevailing rate as per the format of KFS. However, as and when the floating rate changes, only the revised APR may be disclosed to the customer via SMS/ e-mail each time the revised APR becomes applicable.

faqs.question: Is it mandatory to include insurance charges in the calculation of APR?
faqs.answer: The insurance charges shall be included in the computation of APR only for the insurance which is linked/integrated in loan products as these charges are intrinsic to the nature of such digital loans.

faqs.question: Whether the flow of funds between the bank accounts of borrower and lender in a lending transaction can be controlled directly or indirectly by a third-party including LSP?
faqs.answer: No

faqs.question: Can the services of Payment Aggregators (PA) be used for loan disbursals and repayments?
faqs.answer: The principle underlying the Digital Lending Guidelines is that a LSP should not be involved in handling of funds flowing from the lender to the borrower or vice versa. While entities offering only PA services shall remain out of the ambit of ‘Guidelines on Digital Lending’, any PA also performing the role of an LSP must comply with the Digital Lending Guidelines.

faqs.question: In case of delinquent loans, recovery/ servicing of digital loans may be undertaken by a recovery agent collecting cash from borrowers. Will such cases be exempted from the requirement of direct repayment of loan in the RE’s bank account?
faqs.answer: In case of delinquent loans, REs can deploy physical interface to recover loans in cash, where absolutely necessary. In order to afford operational flexibility to REs, such transactions are exempted from the requirement of direct repayment of loan in the RE’s bank account. However, any recovery by cash should be duly reflected in the borrower’s account and REs shall ensure that any fees, charges, etc., payable to LSPs are paid directly by them (REs) and are not charged by LSP to the borrower directly or indirectly from the recovery proceeds.

faqs.question: In certain cases, such as loan products involving advances against salary, though the loan is disbursed directly to the bank account of the borrower, the repayment is from the corporate employer, which deducts the EMI amount from the salary. Whether in such cases, it still has to be ensured that repayment is directly from the bank account of the borrower?
faqs.answer: Such repayments can be allowed subject to the condition that the loan is repaid by the corporate employer by deducting the amount from the borrower’s salary. Further, REs should ensure that LSPs do not have any control over the flow of funds directly or indirectly in such transactions. It has also to be ensured that repayment is directly from the bank account of the employer to the RE.

faqs.question: For co-lending transactions, exemption has been granted from direct disbursal to the bank account of the borrower to the extent of flow of money between REs. Is such exemption available only for co-lending transactions undertaken for priority sector lending?
faqs.answer: The exemption can be extended to co-lending arrangements between REs for non-PSL loans subject to the condition that no third party other than the REs in a co-lending transaction should have direct or indirect control over the flow of funds at any point of time.

faqs.question: Whether the Guidelines are also applicable for corporate including MSME loans?
faqs.answer: The Guidelines are applicable to all transactions meeting the definition of ‘Digital Lending’ as per Digital Lending Guidelines.

faqs.question: Whether the Guidelines are also applicable to mobile banking apps/websites of banks where, as an additional feature, personal loans or loans against deposits are being offered on the applications?
faqs.answer: The Guidelines are applicable to ‘digital loans’ offered over any digital platform which meet the definition of ‘Digital Lending Apps/ Platforms’ (DLAs) as per our circular dated September 02, 2022 on Guidelines on Digital Lending.

faqs.question: Para 4.2 of the Digital Lending Guidelines mandate that penal interest/charges levied shall be based on the outstanding amount of the loan. Whether penal interest/charges can be levied on a lower base?
faqs.answer: The amount under default shall act as the ceiling on which the penal charges can be levied.

faqs.question: Cheque bounce or mandate failure charges are levied on per instance/occurrence basis. Is it mandatory to annualize these charges also?
faqs.answer: Penal charges such as cheque bounce/mandate failure charges, which are necessarily levied on a per instance basis may not be annualized. However, these charges must be disclosed separately in the KFS under ‘Details about Contingent Charges’.

faqs.question: Is processing fees required to be refunded if customer exits the loan during cooling-off period?
faqs.answer: Reasonable one-time processing fee can be retained if the customer exits the loan during cooling-off period. This, if applicable, should be disclosed to the customer upfront in KFS. However, the processing fee has to be mandatorily included for the computation of APR.

faqs.question: If APR is disclosed in KFS, is there a need to also disclose annualised rate of interest to the borrowers as required under Fair Practices Code applicable to NBFCs?
faqs.answer: Yes.

faqs.question: Who is an NRI?
faqs.answer: A ‘Non-resident Indian’ (NRI) is a person resident outside India who is a citizen of India.

faqs.question: Who is a PIO?
faqs.answer: A ‘Person of Indian Origin (PIO)’ is a person resident outside India who is a citizen of any country other than Bangladesh or Pakistan or such other country as may be specified by the Central Government, satisfying certain conditions.

faqs.question: Can a Bangladeshi/Pakistani national or an entity owned/controlled from Bangladesh/Pakistan have an account in India?
faqs.answer: Opening of accounts by individuals/entities of Pakistan nationality/ownership and entities of Bangladesh ownership requires prior approval of the Reserve Bank. However, individuals of Bangladesh nationality can open an NRO account subject to valid visa and residential permit.

faqs.question: What are the accounts that a tourist visiting India can open?
faqs.answer: An NRO (current/savings) account can be opened by a foreign national of non-Indian origin visiting India, with funds remitted from outside India or by sale of foreign exchange brought to India.

faqs.question: What is an SNRR account? How is it different from an NRO account?
faqs.answer: An SNRR (Special Non-Resident Rupee) account is for business-related transactions by non-residents, whereas an NRO account is primarily for personal transactions by non-residents.

faqs.question: What are the deposits that foreign Diplomatic missions/personnel and their family members in India can hold?
faqs.answer: Foreign diplomatic missions and personnel can open rupee deposits, Diplomatic Bond Stores Accounts, and foreign currency accounts in India with specific conditions.

faqs.question: Can persons resident in Nepal and Bhutan have accounts in India?
faqs.answer: Yes, persons resident in Nepal and Bhutan can open Indian rupee accounts with an authorised dealer in India.

faqs.question: Can multilateral organisations have deposits in India?
faqs.answer: Yes, any multilateral organization, of which India is a member nation, or its subsidiary/affiliate bodies and officials in India can open deposits with an authorised dealer in India.

faqs.question: Can an Indian company accept deposits from non-residents in compliance with section 160 of the Companies Act, 2013?
faqs.answer: Yes, such acceptance of deposits and refunds, if required, will be covered under current account transactions and can be made freely without any restriction from FEMA perspective.

faqs.question: Can a Foreign Portfolio Investor or a Foreign Venture Capital Investor open a foreign currency account in India?
faqs.answer: Yes, both Foreign Portfolio Investors and Foreign Venture Capital Investors, registered with SEBI, can open and maintain a non-interest bearing foreign currency account for investment purposes.

faqs.question: Who can open an Escrow Account in India and for what purpose?
faqs.answer: Resident and Non-resident acquirers can open an Escrow Account in INR with an AD bank in India for acquisition/transfer of capital instruments/convertible notes as per Foreign Exchange Management regulations.

faqs.question: What is the definition of 'Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account' (BSBDA)?
faqs.answer: All existing ‘No-frills’ accounts converted into BSBDA in compliance with the guidelines issued on August 17, 2012, as well as fresh accounts opened under the same circular, should be treated as BSBDA.

faqs.question: Whether the guidelines on 'No-frills' accounts with 'nil' or low minimum balances continue after the introduction of BSBDA?
faqs.answer: No. Banks must now offer 'Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account' instead of 'No-frills' accounts and must convert all existing 'No-frills' accounts into BSBDA.

faqs.question: Can an individual have multiple 'Basic Savings Bank Deposit Accounts' in one bank?
faqs.answer: No. An individual is eligible to have only one 'Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account' in one bank.

faqs.question: Can a 'Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account' holder open another savings bank account in the same bank?
faqs.answer: No. Holders of BSBDA cannot open another savings bank account in the same bank. If they already have one, they must close it within 30 days of opening a BSBDA.

faqs.question: Can a BSBDA holder have other deposit accounts such as Fixed Deposits or Recurring Deposits?
faqs.answer: Yes. BSBDA holders can open Term Deposits, Fixed Deposits, or Recurring Deposits in the same bank.

faqs.question: Is BSBDA only for economically weaker sections of the population?
faqs.answer: No. BSBDA is a normal banking service available to all customers.

faqs.question: Are there any restrictions on age, income, or balance for opening a BSBDA?
faqs.answer: No. Banks are not allowed to impose any such restrictions.

faqs.question: Is BSBDA part of the RBI's Financial Inclusion initiative?
faqs.answer: Yes. The introduction of BSBDA is part of RBI's efforts for furthering Financial Inclusion.

faqs.question: What are the KYC norms for BSBDA? Are there any relaxations?
faqs.answer: BSBDA is subject to RBI's KYC/AML norms. If opened with simplified KYC, it is treated as a 'BSBDA-Small Account' and subject to additional conditions.

faqs.question: Can a customer hold both a ‘Small Account’ and a 'Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account' in the same bank?
faqs.answer: No. If BSBDA is opened with simplified KYC, it will also be considered a 'Small Account' and subject to additional conditions.

faqs.question: What are the conditions for 'BSBDA-Small Accounts'?
faqs.answer: Conditions include credit limits of ₹1 lakh per year, maximum balance of ₹50,000, withdrawal limit of ₹10,000 per month, and restrictions on foreign remittances.

faqs.question: What services are available for free in a BSBDA?
faqs.answer: Free services include deposit/withdrawal of cash, receipt of money via electronic payment channels, and cheque deposit at bank branches and ATMs.

faqs.question: Is there any minimum deposit required for opening a BSBDA?
faqs.answer: No. There is no requirement for any initial deposit.

faqs.question: Can banks offer additional facilities beyond the basic services in a BSBDA?
faqs.answer: Yes, banks may offer additional facilities but must transparently disclose any applicable charges. Accounts availing additional chargeable services will not be classified as BSBDA.

faqs.question: If a BSBDA holder exceeds four withdrawals in a month or requests a cheque book, will it still be considered a BSBDA?
faqs.answer: No. If additional chargeable facilities are availed, the account ceases to be a BSBDA.

faqs.question: Do BSBDA holders get the same five free ATM withdrawals per month as regular savings accounts?
faqs.answer: No. Banks must provide a minimum of four free withdrawals per month, including all modes of withdrawal.

faqs.question: Can banks charge an annual fee for ATM Debit Cards issued under BSBDA?
faqs.answer: No. ATM Debit Cards must be provided free of charge with no annual fees.

faqs.question: Does checking balance at an ATM count as one of the four free withdrawals in a BSBDA?
faqs.answer: No. Balance inquiries at ATMs should not be counted as withdrawals.

faqs.question: Can a BSBDA holder opt not to have an ATM Debit Card?
faqs.answer: Yes. ATM Debit Cards should be issued only if requested in writing by the customer.

faqs.question: How should banks handle illiterate or elderly customers regarding ATM Debit Cards?
faqs.answer: Banks should educate such customers on ATM usage and security. If they choose not to have an ATM card, banks should not force them to accept one.

faqs.question: Are BSBDA holders entitled to free passbooks?
faqs.answer: Yes. Banks must provide passbooks free of charge.

faqs.question: What happens if a customer does not close their existing savings account after opening a BSBDA?
faqs.answer: The bank may close the existing savings account after 30 days with prior written consent from the customer.

faqs.question: Can banks allow more than four withdrawals in a month for MGNREGA-linked accounts?
faqs.answer: Yes, but any additional withdrawals beyond four may be chargeable at the discretion of the bank.

faqs.question: What is the interest rate on a BSBDA balance?
faqs.answer: Interest rates on BSBDA follow RBI's deregulation guidelines for savings bank deposits.

faqs.question: Can banks prescribe a minimum balance requirement if a BSBDA customer requests a payable-at-par or multi-city cheque book?
faqs.answer: No. Banks may provide cheque books for free (keeping the account as BSBDA) or charge for them, in which case the account will not be classified as BSBDA.

faqs.question: What is the deadline for banks to convert 'No-Frills' accounts to BSBDA and issue ATM Cards?
faqs.answer: All existing 'No-Frills' accounts should have been converted to BSBDA from August 17, 2012. New accounts should be provided with prescribed facilities immediately upon opening.

faqs.question: Can an existing savings account be converted into a BSBDA upon request?
faqs.answer: Yes. Customers must give written consent, and banks must inform them of the features and limitations of BSBDA.

faqs.question: What are various types of cards?
faqs.answer: Cards can be classified into three types based on their issuance, usage, and payment by the cardholder: (a) Debit cards, (b) Credit cards, and (c) Prepaid cards.

faqs.question: Who issues these cards?
faqs.answer: Debit cards are issued by banks and linked to bank accounts. Credit cards are issued by scheduled commercial banks (excluding payments banks), Regional Rural Banks (in collaboration with other banks), Urban Cooperative Banks, and Non-Banking Financial Companies (subject to RBI approval). Prepaid cards are issued by eligible banks and authorized non-banks.

faqs.question: What are the usages of debit cards?
faqs.answer: Debit cards can be used for cash withdrawals at ATMs, purchases at PoS terminals, and e-commerce transactions. They can be used domestically or internationally.

faqs.question: What are the usages of credit cards?
faqs.answer: Credit cards can be used for purchasing goods and services at PoS terminals or through e-commerce platforms, both domestically and internationally (if enabled). They can also be used for cash advances at ATMs, subject to applicable terms and conditions.

faqs.question: What are the usages of prepaid cards?
faqs.answer: Prepaid cards can be Small PPIs or Full-KYC PPIs. Small PPIs can be used only at specific merchant locations. Full-KYC PPIs can be used for purchases, funds transfer, and cash withdrawal.

faqs.question: What are various methods of using a card at a PoS terminal?
faqs.answer: Cards can be used at PoS terminals in three ways: (a) Dipping (Chip-based card), (b) Tapping (Contactless NFC Card), and (c) Swiping (Magnetic Stripe Card).

faqs.question: What are Magnetic Stripe cards, EMV Chip & PIN cards, and Contactless NFC cards?
faqs.answer: EMV Chip & PIN cards store data in a chip, while Magnetic Stripe cards store data on a magnetic stripe. Contactless NFC cards use near-field communication to make transactions without physical contact. EMV Chip & PIN and Contactless NFC cards are considered safer than Magnetic Stripe cards.

faqs.question: What are Card Present (CP) and Card Not Present (CNP) transactions?
faqs.answer: CP transactions require physical presence of the card (e.g., ATM or PoS transactions). CNP transactions do not require the physical presence of the card (e.g., online or mobile banking transactions).

faqs.question: Who decides the limits for cash withdrawal or purchases using a card?
faqs.answer: The card issuer sets limits on cash withdrawal and purchases. Cardholders can modify transaction limits for domestic, international, PoS, ATM, online, and contactless transactions.

faqs.question: How can a customer know if a fraudulent transaction has taken place on their card?
faqs.answer: RBI mandates card issuers to send alerts for all transactions via SMS/email. Cardholders should register for alerts to stay informed.

faqs.question: How are transactions carried out through cards protected against fraudulent usage?
faqs.answer: All CP and CNP transactions require an Additional Factor of Authentication (AFA) like PIN, OTP, or static code. Contactless NFC transactions up to ₹5,000 per transaction do not require AFA.

faqs.question: What are the liabilities of a card issuer in case of fraudulent use of a card by an unauthorized person?
faqs.answer: For CNP transactions without AFA, the issuer must reimburse the loss to the customer. Customer liability is limited as per RBI guidelines on unauthorized electronic payment transactions.

faqs.question: Can I continue to withdraw money from my Paytm Payments Bank account after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: Yes. You can withdraw or transfer funds up to the available balance in your account.

faqs.question: Can I deposit or transfer money into my Paytm Payments Bank account after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: No. Deposits and transfers into Paytm Payments Bank accounts will not be allowed after March 15, 2024, except for interest, cashback, sweep-ins, and refunds.

faqs.question: Can refunds be credited to my Paytm Payments Bank account after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: Yes. Refunds, cashbacks, and interest can be credited even after March 15, 2024.

faqs.question: What will happen to deposits maintained with partner banks through ‘sweep in/out’ arrangements after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: Existing deposits can be brought back (sweep-in) to Paytm Payments Bank accounts, subject to a balance limit of ₹2 lakh per customer.

faqs.question: Can I continue receiving my salary in my Paytm Payments Bank account after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: No. Salary credits will not be allowed after March 15, 2024. Customers should arrange an alternative bank account before this date.

faqs.question: Can I continue receiving government subsidies and benefits in my Paytm Payments Bank account after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: No. Customers should update their bank details to a different bank before March 15, 2024.

faqs.question: Can my automatic bill payments through Paytm Payments Bank continue after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: Auto-debits will continue until balance is available, but no new deposits will be allowed after March 15, 2024.

faqs.question: Can I continue using my Paytm Payments Bank wallet after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: Yes. You can use the balance in your wallet, but you cannot add new funds after March 15, 2024.

faqs.question: Can I recharge my FASTag issued by Paytm Payments Bank after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: No. Recharges will not be allowed after March 15, 2024. You should obtain a new FASTag from another bank.

faqs.question: Can I continue using my National Common Mobility Card (NCMC) issued by Paytm Payments Bank after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: Yes. You can use the existing balance, but no top-ups or recharges will be allowed after March 15, 2024.

faqs.question: Can I make payments using Bharat Bill Payment System (BBPS) from my Paytm Payments Bank account?
faqs.answer: Yes. Payments can be made until the available balance is exhausted, but no further deposits will be allowed.

faqs.question: Can I transfer money into my Paytm Payments Bank account using UPI/IMPS after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: No. You cannot transfer money into your Paytm Payments Bank account after March 15, 2024.

faqs.question: Can I withdraw money from my Paytm Payments Bank account using UPI/IMPS after March 15, 2024?
faqs.answer: Yes. Withdrawals will be allowed up to the available balance.

faqs.question: What happens to my Paytm Payments Bank account if it has been frozen due to legal orders?
faqs.answer: Any legal freeze or lien on your account will continue as per the orders of law enforcement or judicial authorities.

faqs.question: What happens to my Paytm Payments Bank account if there is an internal freeze?
faqs.answer: Withdrawals and transfers will be allowed up to the available balance, subject to internal bank policies.

faqs.question: Can Paytm Payments Bank onboard new customers after March 11, 2022?
faqs.answer: No. RBI has restricted Paytm Payments Bank from onboarding new customers since March 11, 2022.

faqs.question: What should a customer do if a credit card is issued without his/her consent (unsolicited card)?
faqs.answer: Card issuers are prohibited from issuing unsolicited credit cards and must seek explicit consent. If a customer receives an unsolicited card, they should refrain from activating it and file a complaint with the issuer. If no consent is received, the issuer must close the credit card account within seven working days and notify the customer.

faqs.question: Can a card be issued to other loan accounts such as overdraft facility, cash credit facility, working capital loan, etc.?
faqs.answer: Yes, credit cards can be linked to loan accounts like overdrafts or business credit cards, subject to the terms of the loan. However, debit cards cannot be issued to cash credit or loan accounts.

faqs.question: What can be considered as activation of a credit card?
faqs.answer: Activation includes customer-initiated actions such as PIN generation, modifying transaction controls, IVR calls, or SMS confirmation. If the card is not activated within 30 days, issuers must seek OTP-based consent.

faqs.question: Can a credit card be considered as ‘used’ even if no financial transactions have been undertaken?
faqs.answer: Yes, activities like generating a statement, changing PIN, or modifying transaction controls are considered usage. However, calls to customer care for other reasons are not considered usage.

faqs.question: Can consent for activation and closure of a business credit card be obtained from the corporate entity instead of the cardholder?
faqs.answer: Yes, for business credit cards, consent must be obtained from the principal account holder (corporate entity). For retail credit cards, consent is required from the primary cardholder, not add-on cardholders.

faqs.question: In case a cardholder makes partial payment, can a card-issuer charge interest/levy late payment charges on the total amount due?
faqs.answer: No, interest should be charged only on the outstanding amount after adjusting payments/refunds. Late payment fees should also be applied only to the outstanding amount and not the total amount due.

faqs.question: Can a credit card-issuer levy interest on unpaid taxes/levies/charges?
faqs.answer: No, issuers are not allowed to capitalize interest on unpaid taxes/levies/charges. This rule has been in effect since October 1, 2022.

faqs.question: What transactions can be adjusted towards outstanding dues or credited to the cardholder’s bank account?
faqs.answer: Refunds received before bill generation adjust the Total Amount Due (TAD). Refunds after bill generation adjust the outstanding balance. Refunds after payment require explicit consent for adjustment; otherwise, they are credited to the bank account.

faqs.question: Can a cardholder modify the billing cycle of a credit card to any date?
faqs.answer: Yes, cardholders must be given the option to select or modify the billing cycle at least once through multiple channels like helpline, email, IVR, internet banking, or mobile apps.

faqs.question: Can a card-issuer allow a credit card to be used beyond the sanctioned credit limit and charge overlimit fees?
faqs.answer: No, overlimit usage requires prior explicit consent from the cardholder. Issuers must provide an option to enable/disable overlimit transactions through online banking or mobile apps.

faqs.question: Can interest, taxes, or other charges be considered for computing a cardholder’s credit limit usage for overlimit fees?
faqs.answer: No, interest or other charges should not be included when computing a cardholder’s credit limit for levying overlimit charges.

faqs.question: Does liability towards credit card dues rest only with the principal cardholder?
faqs.answer: Yes, the principal cardholder is solely responsible for credit card dues, except for business credit cards where liability is governed by the agreement terms.

faqs.question: Are card-issuers required to provide insurance cover on debit and credit cards?
faqs.answer: No, RBI does not mandate insurance for debit or credit cards. However, if issuers provide insurance, they must inform customers about coverage details and insurer contact information in statements.

faqs.question: Can a card-issuer partner with more than one co-branding partner for a card?
faqs.answer: Yes, a card-issuer can collaborate with multiple co-branding partners.

faqs.question: Can a co-branding partner acting as a business correspondent (BC) or technology service provider access cardholder transaction data?
faqs.answer: No, co-branding partners cannot access transaction data. Data can only be displayed securely on their platform without storage or access.

faqs.question: Does deactivation/blocking of a credit card amount to closure of the card account?
faqs.answer: No, blocking a credit card temporarily suspends transactions but does not close the account. Closure requires a formal request, which must be processed within seven working days.

faqs.question: What is the procedure for filing a complaint against a card issuer?
faqs.answer:
Customers should first approach the card issuer. If unresolved within 30 days, they can file a complaint with the RBI Ombudsman via: 
1. Online at https://cms.rbi.org.in 
2. By post to the Centralized Receipt and Processing Centre, RBI, Sector-17, Chandigarh - 160017.

faqs.question: What is tokenisation?
faqs.answer: Tokenisation refers to the replacement of actual card details with an alternate code called the 'token,' which is unique for a combination of card, token requestor, and device.

faqs.question: What is de-tokenisation?
faqs.answer: De-tokenisation is the process of converting the token back to actual card details.

faqs.question: What is the benefit of tokenisation?
faqs.answer: Tokenised card transactions are considered safer because actual card details are not shared with merchants during transaction processing.

faqs.question: How can tokenisation be carried out?
faqs.answer: The cardholder can request tokenisation via an app provided by the token requestor. The token requestor forwards the request to the card network, which, with the issuer's consent, issues a corresponding token.

faqs.question: What are the charges for availing tokenisation services?
faqs.answer: The customer does not need to pay any charges for tokenisation services.

faqs.question: What are the use cases for which tokenisation has been allowed?
faqs.answer: Tokenisation is allowed on consumer devices such as mobile phones, tablets, laptops, desktops, wearables (wristwatches, bands, etc.), and IoT devices for various transactions like contactless card payments, QR code payments, and in-app payments.

faqs.question: Can tokenisation be enabled through a smartwatch or similar devices?
faqs.answer: Yes, tokenisation is available on devices such as smartwatches, mobile phones, tablets, desktops, and IoT devices.

faqs.question: Who can perform tokenisation and de-tokenisation?
faqs.answer: Tokenisation and de-tokenisation can be performed by the authorised card network or the card issuer.

faqs.question: Who are the stakeholders in a tokenisation transaction?
faqs.answer: A tokenised card transaction involves multiple stakeholders: merchant, merchant’s acquirer, token service provider (card network or issuer), token requestor, card issuer, and customer.

faqs.question: Are customer card details safe after tokenisation?
faqs.answer: Yes, actual card data, tokens, and relevant details are stored securely by the token service provider. The token requestor cannot store the card number or other details.

faqs.question: Is tokenisation of a card mandatory for customers?
faqs.answer: No, customers can choose whether or not to have their card tokenised.

faqs.question: Can customers select tokenisation for a specific use case?
faqs.answer: Yes, customers can register or de-register their card for specific use cases such as contactless payments, QR code transactions, and in-app payments.

faqs.question: How does the process of registration for a tokenisation request work?
faqs.answer: Registration for tokenisation requires explicit customer consent through Additional Factor of Authentication (AFA). The customer can also select use cases and set transaction limits.

faqs.question: Can customers set their own limits for tokenised transactions?
faqs.answer: Yes, customers can set and modify per-transaction and daily transaction limits for tokenised card transactions.

faqs.question: Is there a limit on the number of cards a customer can tokenise?
faqs.answer: No, customers can request tokenisation for any number of cards.

faqs.question: Can customers select which card to use if they have multiple tokenised cards?
faqs.answer: Yes, customers are free to use any of their tokenised cards for a transaction.

faqs.question: Is there a limit on the number of devices on which a card can be tokenised?
faqs.answer: No, customers can request tokenisation of their card on any number of devices.

faqs.question: Whom should customers contact in case of issues with their tokenised card? Where can they report loss of a device?
faqs.answer: Customers should contact their card issuer for any issues or to report the loss of a device.

faqs.question: Can a card issuer refuse tokenisation of a particular card?
faqs.answer: Yes, based on risk perception, card issuers may decide whether to allow tokenisation for specific cards.

faqs.question: Where can more information on RBI instructions on tokenisation be found?
faqs.answer: More details can be found in RBI circulars issued on January 8, 2019, August 25, 2021, and September 7, 2021.
